content.text: State how a vector quantity differs from a scalar quantity
Circle the vector quantities in the list
acceleration energy mass momentum temperature time speed speed velocity
Calculate \(W.\)
W =
The microphone is suspended from the ceiling by a cord attached to a small ring. Fig. 1.1 shows the microphone pulled to one side and kept stationary by a horizontal thread
State and explain how the magnitude and direction of the resultant in (c)(ii) compares with the force on the ring due to the tension in the cord
A microphone in a recording studio has a mass of \(0.55\mathrm{kg}\) and a weight \(W.\)
Some physical quantities are scalars and other physical quantities are vectors
Define thermal capacity
Give a simple molecular account of this decrease in internal energy
The specific heat capacity of water is \(4200 \text{J} / (\text{kg} \text{°C})\)
Calculate the decrease in the internal energy of the water as its temperature decreases from \(17^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) to \(0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
decrease in internal energy =   .........
Several ice cubes are at a temperature of \(0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}.\) The ice cubes are dropped into the water and the internal energy of the water decreases
Explain why this ice melts
Describe how to determine the specific latent heat of fusion of ice using this experiment. State any other measurements that the student needs to make
As the temperature of the water decreases, some of the ice melts
A student carries out an experiment using a plastic beaker that contains \(0.24 \text{kg}\) of water at \(17^{\circ} \text{C}\). The thermal capacity (heat capacity) of the beaker is negligible
Explain, in terms of the momentum of the molecules, why there is a pressure at the inner surface of the balloon
Calculate the volume of the air when the pressure of the air is \(1.4 \times 10^5 \text{Pa}\)
The balloon and stone stop moving when the stone hits the bottom of the lake. The temperature of the air now begins to decrease
Explain why the volume of the air in the balloon decreases as the temperature decreases
The volume of the air in the balloon is \(630 \text{cm}^3\) and the pressure of the air in the balloon is \(1.0 \times 10^5 \text{Pa}\)
The balloon is tied to a heavy stone and dropped into a lake. The balloon is pulled down quickly and the temperature of the air inside does **not** change
Fig. 3.1 shows a balloon inflated with air
The pressure of the air at the inner surface of the balloon keeps the rubber stretched
a line to represent the motion of the train between \(t = 15 \text{s}\) and \(t = 25 \text{s}\)
a curve to represent the motion of the train between \(t = 0\) and \(t = 15 \text{s}\)
Complete Fig. 4.1 by drawing:
Calculate the kinetic energy of the train between \(t = 15 \text{s}\) and \(t = 25 \text{s}\)
kinetic energy =   .........
Define work done
Using Fig. 4.1, determine the distance moved by the train while it decelerates
distance moved =   .........
Calculate the resultant force acting on the train while it decelerates
resultant force =   .........
While the train decelerates to rest, it does work against the resistive force and its kinetic energy decreases

A train of mass \(1.8 \times 10^{5} \text{kg}\) is at rest in a station. At time \(t = 0\), the train begins to accelerate along a straight, horizontal track and reaches a speed of \(20 \text{m/s}\) at \(t = 15 \text{s}\). The train continues at a speed of \(20 \text{m/s}\) for 10s
At \(t = 25 \text{s}\), the driver applies the brakes and the resistive force on the train causes it to decelerate uniformly to rest in a further 24s
Fig. 4.1 is an incomplete distance–time graph for this journey
Explain, in terms of the behaviour of light rays, what is meant by _principal focus_ for a thin converging lens
State what is meant by _focal length_

Consider the straight ray that passes from the tip of O to the tip of I and find the position of the lens. Mark the position of the lens by drawing a vertical line labelled L from the top of the grid to the bottom
On Fig. 5.1, draw a ray that passes through one of the principal focuses and determine the focal length of the lens
focal length =
Object O is a printed document that includes a large letter R on the side facing the lens. The top edge of the document corresponds to the tip of O. Fig. 5.2 shows the printed document
Fig. 5.2 Fig. 5.3

On Fig. 5.3, mark a tick in **one** of the boxes \((\text{✓})\) to indicate how the image on the translucent screen appears to someone who is looking at the screen from point P. Explain why the image has this appearance
A lens is used to produce a focused image of an object on a translucent screen. Fig. 5.1 shows the object O and its image I
State the names of these three components
J
K
L
State which of these three components has the lowest frequency
Three components of the spectrum are unnamed but labelled J, K and L
Calculate the frequency of X-rays that have a wavelength of \(1.2 \times 10^{-9} \text{m}\) in a vacuum
frequency =   .........
Describe **one** medical use of X-rays
State one reason why it is necessary to take safety precautions when X-rays are used
X-rays are electromagnetic waves. Fig. 6.1 shows the position of X-rays in the electromagnetic spectrum arranged according to increasing wavelength
Describe, in terms of particles, how the rod becomes negatively charged when rubbed with the cloth
Explain why the ball jumps up
The ball touches the rod and falls back down to the table
Explain why this happens
A light, conducting ball is at rest on a metal table. When the rod is brought close to the ball, as shown in Fig. 7.1, the ball jumps up towards the rod
A plastic rod becomes negatively charged when it is rubbed with a woollen cloth
State what is meant by electric current
The current in the LDR is \(I_{1}\) and the current in the \(800\Omega\) resistor is \(I_{2}\)
Complete the equation that relates the current in the \(450\Omega\) resistor to \(I_{1}\) and \(I_{2}\)
current in the \(450\Omega\) resistor =
Calculate the power dissipated in the \(800\Omega\) resistor
power =
The brightness of the light that is incident on the LDR increases
Explain what happens to the potential difference (p.d.) across the \(450 \Omega\) resistor
A circuit contains two fixed resistors and a light-dependent resistor (LDR). Fig. 8.1 shows that the power supply is a \(9.0 \text{V}\) battery
The current in the \(450\Omega\) resistor is 0.012A
Describe the composition and structure of a neutral atom of uranium-235
Another isotope of uranium is uranium-238
Describe how an atom of uranium-238 differs from an atom of uranium-235
In the reactor in a nuclear power station, a nucleus of uranium-235 absorbs a slow-moving neutron and then undergoes nuclear fission
Two neutrons, a nucleus of xenon-140 ( \(^{140}_{54}\mathrm {Xe})\) and a nucleus of an element represented by E are produced
Complete the equation for this fission reaction
the proton number of Q
the nucleon number of Q
Xenon-140 ( \(^{140}_{54}\mathrm {Xe})\) is radioactive. It decays by \(\beta\) -emission to isotope Q
Determine:
Uranium-235 ( \(^{235}_{92}\mathrm {U})\) is a radioactive isotope of uranium that occurs naturally on Earth
